text.title: Unit Three: Adjectives; Possessive and Demonstrative Pronouns

paragraphs.content: Adjectives in Italian must agree in **gender** and **number** with the noun they refer to: if the noun is **masculine singular** the adjective must be **masculine singular**, if the noun is **feminine singular** the adjective must be **feminine singular**, etc. Adjectives therefore change their forms accordingly. But remember that when an adjective is listed in a dictionary or a grammar, it is given in its **masculine singular** form. In the **masculine singular**, most Italian adjectives end in **-o** or in **-e**:
Adjectives ending in **-o** have four different forms:
Adjectives ending in **-e** have only two forms:
With adjectives ending in **-e** there is thus no difference between the **masculine** and **feminine** form:
Some adjectives end in **-a**, like the following:

These adjectives have three forms: **-a** for the **masculine** and **feminine singular** (**ottimista**), **-i** for the **masculine plural** (**ottimisti**) and **-e** for the **feminine plural** (**ottimiste**). There is thus only one form for the **masculine** and **feminine singular**:
* For an explanation of the **-h-** in **belghe**, see paragraph 3.06.
There are also some invariable adjectives, e.g. **blu** (dark blue), **rosa** (pink), **dispari** (odd), **pari** (even), which do not change:

Care is needed in spelling the plural of adjectives ending in **-co** and **-go**. There is no fixed rule for the **masculine** forms, which may keep the hard sound of **c** and **g** and add **h** (**-chi**, **-ghi**), or change the sound of **c** and **g** in the plural (**-ci**, **-gi**). The **feminine plural** forms always add **h** (**-che**, **-ghe**) in order to keep the hard sound of **c** and **g**. If in doubt, check in a dictionary; the best way to remember these sorts of plural is through practice:
The adjective **belga**, as we have seen, keeps the hard sound of **g** in the **feminine plural** by adding **h** (**belghe**); but it changes the sound in the **masculine plural** (**belgi**).

As can be seen in the examples, the adjective normally comes after the noun it refers to and (unless it is **invariable**) it must agree in **gender** and **number** with the noun. It must also agree in **gender** and **number** with the noun even where it is separated from it by another word, such as a verb:

rows: Lorenzo, Anna and Claudia are Italian.
The computer and the printer are new.
The bathroom and the kitchen are small.
The trousers and the shirt are new.

paragraphs.content: When the adjective refers to two or more nouns which are different in **gender**, it is **masculine plural**:
In some cases the adjective can also precede the noun it refers to. When the adjective comes before the noun, the meaning of the noun becomes different, as in these examples:

rows: an old/elderly friend [i.e. a friend who is old]
the poor woman [i.e. she has no money]

paragraphs.content: The demonstrative adjectives **questo** (this) and **quello** (that), like their English counterparts, always precede the noun they refer to:
* For an explanation of the forms of **quello**, see paragraph 3.10.

The forms of the adjectives **quello** and **bello** (beautiful/handsome/nice/fine) change in the same way as the **definite article**. Here are the forms, followed in brackets by the corresponding forms of the **definite article**:
Note that when **bello** comes after the noun, the full form is used: **lo spettacolo** è **bello**, **un’esperienza** **bella** e **interessante**, etc.
The forms of the adjective **buono** (good), when used before a **singular** noun, change in the same way as the **indefinite article**:
* Nowadays the form **buona** is preferred to **buon’**.
Note that when **buono** comes after the noun, the full form is used: **questo libro** è **buono**, **il caffè** è **buono**, etc.

The adjective **grande** (big/great), when used before the noun, may change to the **invariable** form **gran** or, in some expressions, to **grand’**; nowadays, the full form, **grande**, is preferred in most cases:
Note that before **plural** nouns, **grande** is regular: **grandi musicisti**, **grandi case**, etc.
Note also that when **grande** comes after the noun, the full form is always used: **quel film** è **grande**, **la casa** è **grande**, etc.
The adjective **santo** (saint) is another that has different forms when used before a noun:
list: **santo** is only used before **masculine** names starting with **s + consonant**;
**san** is used before **masculine** names starting with a **consonant** (other than **s + consonant**);
**sant’** is used before **masculine** or **feminine** names starting with a **vowel**;
**santa** is used before **feminine** names starting with a **consonant**:

paragraphs.content: Note that when **santo** means ‘**holy**’ or ‘**blessed**’, it is regular: **il santo padre** (the Holy Father), **una santa donna** (a holy woman).
The forms of the **possessive adjectives** (‘**my**’, ‘**your**’, etc.) are as follows:
* Note that the **masculine plural** forms **miei**, **tuoi** and **suoi** are irregular.
** Note that **loro** is **invariable** and does not change.
**Possessive adjectives** are always used before the noun they refer to. Unlike in English, they are always preceded by the **article**, and they must agree with the owned object, not with the owner:

When **mio**, **tuo**, **suo**, **nostro** and **vostro** (not **loro**) are used with a noun denoting **family relationship** (e.g. **fratello** (brother), **sorella** (sister), **padre** (father), **madre** (mother)) in the **singular** they are not preceded by the **definite article**:
The forms of the **possessive pronouns** (‘**mine**’, ‘**yours**’, etc.) are the same as those of the **possessive adjectives**, and are always preceded by the **definite article**:

rows: **La tua casa** è grande, ma **la loro** è piccola.
Your house is big, but theirs is small.
**I tuoi CD** sono qui, **i nostri** sono lì.
Your CDs are here, ours are there.

paragraphs.content: As we shall see (Unit 4, paragraph 5), in Italian there is a form used to address people formally. In the formal way of addressing people, the **possessive adjectives** and **pronouns** used are **Suo** for the **singular**, and **Vostro** (or **Loro** if a higher degree of formality is required) for the **plural**:

rows: (Mr and Mrs Bianco,) your room is ready.
(Mr and Mrs Bianco,) your room is ready.

paragraphs.content: Pronouns

rows: **La loro auto** è in strada, ma **la Sua** è in garage, **Signora**.
Their car’s in the street, but yours is in the garage(, Madam).

paragraphs.content: **Questo** and **quello** are also used as **demonstrative pronouns** (**this** (one), **that** (one), **these** (ones), **those** (ones)). But note that when **quello** is used as a **demonstrative pronoun**, its endings are not modelled on the **definite article** (cf. paragraph 3.10), but are the same as those of **questo** (i.e. **quello** [ms], **quella** [fs], **quelli** [mp], **quelle** [fp]):

exercises.instruction: Complete the phrases by choosing the form of the adjective that agrees with the noun.

exercises.title: Exercise 2
exercises.instruction: Choose the right adjective for each noun or pair of nouns.

exercises.title: Exercise 3
exercises.instruction: Complete the sentences by adding the correct form of the **possessive adjective** and, where necessary, the **article**.

exercises.title: Exercise 4
exercises.instruction: Answer the questions using the **possessive pronoun**, according to whether the answer is affirmative or negative.
examples: ‘È **la Sua macchina**, Signor Rossi?’ ‘Sì, è **la mia**.’

exercises.title: Exercise 5
exercises.instruction: Complete the sentences by choosing the right form of the adjectives and pronouns.
examples: (**Questo**) non è (**tuo**) **stanza**, è (**mio**): **Questa** non è **la tua stanza**, è **la mia**.

items.question: (**Questo**) **signori** sono (**nostro**) **ospiti** (**tedesco**).
items.answer: Questi signori sono i nostri ospiti tedeschi.

items.question: (**Suo**) **colleghi** sono (**ottimista**), Signora!
items.answer: I Suoi colleghi sono ottimisti, Signora!

items.question: Io ho (**mio**) **documenti**, Lei ha (**Suo**), Signore?
items.answer: Io ho i miei documenti, Lei ha i Suoi, Signore?

items.question: (**Questo**) sono (**mio**) **CD**, (**quello**) sono (**tuo**).
items.answer: Questi sono i miei CD, quelli sono i tuoi.

items.question: (**Nostro**) **professore** è (**entusiasta**), com’è (**vostro**)?
items.answer: Il nostro professore è entusiasta, com’è il vostro?

items.question: (**Quello**) sono (**mio**) **magliette**, (**questo**) sono (**tuo**).
items.answer: Quelle sono le mie magliette, queste sono le tue.

items.question: (**Quello**) **esercizi** sono (**divertente**), ma (**questo**) è (**difficile**).
items.answer: Quelli esercizi sono divertenti, ma questo è difficile.

items.question: (**Mio**) **bagagli** sono (**pesante**), ma (**vostro**) sono (**leggero**).
items.answer: I miei bagagli sono pesanti, ma i vostri sono leggeri.

items.question: (**Quello**) **acqua** (**minerale**) è (**gassato**), ma (**questo**) è (**liscio**).
items.answer: Quell’acqua minerale è gassata, ma questa è liscia.
